citations.narrative:
The program of veterinary care does not detail testing for internal parasites as described in this section. The program of
veterinary care does not describe preventive care and treatment to ensure healthy haircoats nails, skin, eyes, and clean
ears. The program of veterinary care must include all information detailed in this section. The program of veterinary care
is a required document that APHIS inspectors use to determine the quality of veterinary care for the animals at a facility.
This document must be followed by the licensee to ensure adequate care and treatment of the animals. All schedules,
treatments, and procedures listed in the program of veterinary care must be followed by the licensee.

All dogs at the facility were overdue for their complete physicals by the attending veterinarian. These physicals were last
completed in February 2022. These physicals have not yet been scheduled for these dogs. It is essential that these
physicals be completed as required on a yearly basis in order to ensure that the dogs are healthy. Have these physicals
conducted by the attending veterinarian.

The licensee does not have medical records as described in this section. The medical record does not contain the
required identification information for each dog as well as the dogs breed, sex and age. Information is lacking on results
of physical exams, vaccinations, fecal and heartworm test results, preventive care checks conducted by the licensee and
heartworm prevention. It is required that all preventions, vaccinations, treatments, and testing be recorded in the animal’s
medical record. This information is needed for APHIS inspectors to evaluate the quality of medical care provided by the
facility. Record all treatments, testing, preventions vaccinations and all other medical procedures required by section 3.13
in medical records maintained for each animal at the facility.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 5/2/2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
End Section

narrative:
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The program of veterinary care does not detail testing for internal parasites as described in this section.  The program of 
veterinary care does not describe preventive care and treatment to ensure healthy haircoats nails, skin, eyes, and clean 
ears.  The program of veterinary care must include all information detailed in this section.  The program of veterinary care 
is a required document that APHIS inspectors use to determine the quality of veterinary care for the animals at a facility.  
This document must be followed by the licensee to ensure adequate care and treatment of the animals.  All schedules, 
treatments, and procedures listed in the program of veterinary care must be followed by the licensee. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
All dogs at the facility were overdue for their complete physicals by the attending veterinarian.  These physicals were last 
completed in February 2022.  These physicals have not yet been scheduled for these dogs.  It is essential that these 
physicals be completed as required on a yearly basis in order to ensure that the dogs are healthy.  Have these physicals 
conducted by the attending veterinarian. 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

The licensee does not have medical records as described in this section.  The medical record does not contain the 
required identification information for each dog as well as the dogs breed, sex and age.  Information is lacking on results 
of physical exams, vaccinations, fecal and heartworm test results, preventive care checks conducted by the licensee and 
heartworm prevention.  It is required that all preventions, vaccinations, treatments, and testing be recorded in the animal’s 
medical record.  This information is needed for APHIS inspectors to evaluate the quality of medical care provided by the 
facility.  Record all treatments, testing, preventions vaccinations and all other medical procedures required by section 3.13 
in medical records maintained for each animal at the facility. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 5/2/2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
End Section
